jeopardy_round: CAN I HAVE A WORD WITH YOU?

(1, 1).clue: Albert Einstein was the Person of the Century; in 1949 this British statesman was the man of the half-century

(3, 1).clue: 2 edible types of this shellfish found on the Pacific coast of North America are the Red King & Dungeness

(4, 1).clue: The tagline "Is it live or is it" this brand was introduced in 1971 in ads for recordable audio cassettes

(5, 1).clue: This frequent co-star of Doris Day played Daniel Reece on "Dynasty"

(6, 1).clue: This insect is also known as a dumbledore; same amount of syllables & sounds similar

(1, 2).clue: 1951's & 1979's men were from this country; the first was a Premier, the second a religious zealot

(2, 2).clue: American bomber planes introduced in the 1950s

(3, 2).clue: It's marketed according to size, from Colossal (10 or less to a pound) to miniature (about 100 to a pound)

(4, 2).clue: This brand dates back to a company set up in 1913 to manufacture liquid bleach

(5, 2).clue: He's credited with pushing the Missouri Compromise through the House

(6, 2).clue: This contraction is used to describe, say, an easy golf shot that your opponent excuses you from playing

(1, 3).clue: This Independent Counsel shared the honor with Bill Clinton for 1998

(3, 3).clue: To keep these stalk-eyed beasts from harming each other, rubber bands are put around their claws

(4, 3).clue: The logo of this watch brand, a status symbol, is seen here

(5, 3).clue: In 1975 he replaced Mick Taylor in The Rolling Stones

(6, 3).clue: A kolkhoz was a collective or co-operative communal one in the USSR, sort of like a kibbutz in Israel

(1, 4).clue: For 1974 this King of Saudi Arabia was chosen for the turmoil he unleashed after raising oil prices

(3, 4).clue: It's really an old wives' tale that it's unsafe to eat this bivalve in months without an "R" in their name

(4, 4).clue: "Discover what your lips are missing" is a slogan for this product

(5, 4).clue: Since the 1960s this film producer has been partnered with a merchant

(6, 4).clue: From the Latin for "bad", if you have it "aforethought", you're in big trouble

(1, 5).clue: For 1978 he made it as Vice Premier of China; for 1985 he was picked again, but now he was the Premier

(3, 5).clue: The shell of this mollusk gave its name to a method of cooking & to a curved edge, on cloth, for example

(4, 5).clue: The name of this electronics brand is from the Latin for "great voice"

(5, 5).clue: "Wonders of the Invisible World" was his 1693 book on some of the Salem witchcraft cases

(6, 5).clue: In this foreign sport, Niramiai is the time spent stamping, thigh-slapping & glaring at your opponent before fighting

(1, 1).clue: Although Abner Doubleday organized baseball teams in this village, he didn't invent the game

(2, 1).clue: The story in which she "takes a bawth" at the Plaza was written in the 1960s but wasn't published until 2002

(3, 1).clue: (Sofia of the Clue Crew presents from Wittenberg, Germany) The only achievement mentioned in Luther's epitaph is his doctorate in this subject from Wittenberg University

(4, 1).clue: The razzle-dazzle musical where a sensational murder trial is acted out in vaudeville specialties"

(5, 1).clue: Formed in 1864 to take care of battle victims, it now relieves human suffering worldwide

(1, 2).clue: It was the capital of colonial Virginia from 1619 to 1699

(2, 2).clue: A Disney film was based on this 1959 Margery Sharp tale of Miss Bianca & the mice of the Prisoners' Aid Society

(3, 2).clue: Terrified by a storm, Luther swore he'd become one of these, & joined the Augustinian order

(4, 2).clue: David Henry Hwang has redone the book for this 1958 tale of romance in San Francisco's Chinatown

(5, 2).clue: This actress is the founding national chair of AmFAR, the American Foundation for AIDS Research

(6, 2).clue: Of the nursery rhyme "Old King Cole"

(1, 3).clue: When construction began on this planned community on Long Island in 1946, a house sold for $7,000

(2, 3).clue: A pilot who's crashed in the Sahara narrates this tale written & illustrated by Saint-Exupery

(3, 3).clue: In translating the Bible, Luther added "alone" after this word, believing that it, rather than works, saves us

(5, 3).clue: Founded in 1971, in French its name is Medecins Sans Frontieres

(4, 4).clue: First name of Patrick Dennis' aunt; Angela Lansbury was first to play her in the musical

(5, 4).clue: It helps people in crisis due to homelessness or mobility problems & has offices in bus stations & airports
